What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course was highly enriching as the material covered both theories and case studies of issues surrounding race and inequality - most of which I did not have deep knowledge of. It has been an eye opener.
Learned a lot about inequalities present and formed through public housing and its developments.
This was a good class to start learning about Urban studies. It was definitely not an intro class, but Professor Barnes made the material accessible to those that weren't familiar with Urbanism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Discussions were very lively and the professor's opinions were valuable. However, there might have been too much material planned initially.

The class had good material for the most part and was a very interesting topic, especially with how relevant it is in the present. That being said, the readings weren't picked most efficiently  much of the class was reading two entire books, where most of the information we needed could be found in a few chapters therein and other necessary information could be quickly summarized in a class presentation. There was often missing class time because Prof. Barnes is often late to class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it covers issues that are highly pertinent
As long as Prof. Barnes tweaks the course, which I have no doubt she will, this is a beautiful course that it incredibly relevant.
